newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada bonds end stronger in thin, illiquid market.
newsitem.headline: Canada bonds end stronger in thin, illiquid market.

text.p: Canadian bonds closed stronger on Friday, with spreads to U.S. long bonds narrowing sharply, but with gains seen as negligible in light of very low trading volumes, analysts said.

"They are closing positive with a pretty firm tone, but once again the caveat how low volume is. It's easy to push around prices," said Jeoff Hall, a Canadian market analyst with financial analysis firm Technical Data.
Canada's 30-year benchmark bond rose C$0.95 to C$111.40 to yield 7.043 percent. The U.S. 30-year bond fell 3/32 to yield 6.59 percent.
The spread between the benchmark bonds narrowed to 45 basis points from 52 basis points at the close of trading on Thursday.
"I don't know if I'd really say it's positive. It's more just illiquid. No one is trading it, so the people who want to push it can push it," said one T-bill trader.
Dealers said most desks were thinly staffed with the holiday season and an industry luncheon in Toronto keeping many traders away.
Canadian bonds made sharp gains despite stronger than expected Canadian economic data.
Canada's wholesale trade rose a higher-than-expected 1.7 percent seasonally adjusted in October, Statistics Canada said this morning.

The government agency also said the preliminary estimate of average weekly earnings for Canadian workers in all industries except agriculture and fishing rose a higher than 3.0 percent in October from a year earlier.
In other prices, the Government of Canada 7.0 percent bond due 2006 rose C$0.43 to C$104.25 to 6.414 percent. The U.S. 10-year bond fell 3/32 to yield 6.34 percent.
The spread between the bonds narrowed to 7 basis points from 14 basis points at Thursday's close.
Canada's three-month cash bill traded at 2.88 percent against the U.S. bill at 5.02 percent.
